articles.headline: A Bonus Is Declined; a Problem Remains
articles.snippet: IBM’s chief executive and others have refused their annual bonuses, mostly as a symbolic gesture to account for poor performance, but that raises the question of why they were receiving bonuses in the first place.
articles.abstract: IBM’s chief executive and others have refused their annual bonuses, mostly as a symbolic gesture to account for poor performance, but that raises the question of why they were receiving bonuses in the first place.
articles.lead_paragraph: When IBM reported fourth-quarter and full-year earnings a few weeks ago, they could have been an excuse for popping champagne corks in the executive suite.

articles.headline: Plan to Limit Some Drugs in Medicare Is Criticized
articles.snippet: Health care groups and members of Congress are opposing an Obama administration proposal to limit coverage for three classes of drugs.
articles.abstract: Health care groups and members of Congress are opposing an Obama administration proposal to limit coverage for three classes of drugs.
articles.lead_paragraph: An alliance of drug companies and patient advocates, joined by Democrats and Republicans in Congress, is fiercely opposing an Obama administration proposal that would allow insurers to limit Medicare coverage for certain classes of drugs, including those used to treat depression and schizophrenia.
articles.byline: By Katie Thomas and Robert Pear

articles.headline: In Sake, Japan Sees a Potential Stimulus
articles.snippet: Sake is among the soft goods that the government is promoting to help improve the country’s exports.
articles.abstract: Sake is among the soft goods that the government is promoting to help improve the country’s exports.
articles.lead_paragraph: NIHONMATSU, Japan — As Japan confronts troubling economic data and memories of its stagnant “lost generation,” the country’s government is offering a little something to take the edge off: a bottle or two of sake.
articles.byline: By Eric Pfanner and Zhiyi Yang

articles.headline: Fed Fretted Over Reaction to Demise of Lehman
articles.snippet: The documents published on Friday provide one of the fullest pictures yet of the thinking of top government officials on the bank’s implosion.
articles.abstract: The documents published on Friday provide one of the fullest pictures yet of the thinking of top government officials on the bank’s implosion.
articles.lead_paragraph: Six weeks after Lehman Brothers filed for bankruptcy in September 2008, Ben S. Bernanke, then chairman of the Federal Reserve, gave his central bank colleagues an imitation of the people who were already criticizing the government’s decision to let the Wall Street bank collapse.

articles.headline: Religious Right in Arizona Cheers Bill Allowing Businesses to Refuse to Serve Gays
articles.snippet: Gov. Jan Brewer of Arizona must decide whether to sign the legislation that would allow religious beliefs as a legal justification for denying service to same-sex couples.
articles.abstract: Gov. Jan Brewer of Arizona must decide whether to sign the legislation that would allow religious beliefs as a legal justification for denying service to same-sex couples.
articles.lead_paragraph: In New Mexico, a photographer declined to take pictures of a lesbian couple’s commitment ceremony. In Washington State, a florist would not provide flowers for a same-sex wedding. And in Colorado, a baker refused to make a cake for a party celebrating the wedding of two men.
articles.byline: By Michael Paulson and Fernanda Santos

articles.headline: As Crisis Loomed, Yellen Made Wry and Forceful Calls for Action
articles.snippet: Janet Yellen was a nonvoting member of the Federal Reserve’s policy-making committee as global finances soured, but she called for swift action and disarmed critics with gallows humor.
articles.abstract: Janet Yellen was a nonvoting member of the Federal Reserve’s policy-making committee as global finances soured, but she called for swift action and disarmed critics with gallows humor.
articles.lead_paragraph: As the world’s financial system stood on the verge of collapse in October 2008, Janet L. Yellen was not even a full voting member of the Federal Reserve’s policy-making committee, but she was not shy about admonishing her colleagues for not acting faster.

articles.headline: Amid Fence-Mending, Another U.S.-Russia Rift
articles.snippet: The political crisis in Ukraine has underscored the difficulties of restoring constructive ties between Washington and Moscow.
articles.abstract: The political crisis in Ukraine has underscored the difficulties of restoring constructive ties between Washington and Moscow.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — After putting the tense Russian-American relationship on “pause” last year, President Obama and his team have lately been working to get it back on track by quietly planning a possible meeting this summer with President Vladimir V. Putin. The two sides have even begun discussing a trade agreement for the two to sign.

articles.headline: WhatsApp Deal Bets on a Few Fewer ‘Friends’
articles.snippet: In buying WhatsApp, Facebook is betting that the future of social networking will depend on the ability to quickly and efficiently communicate with your closest confidants.
articles.abstract: In buying WhatsApp, Facebook is betting that the future of social networking will depend on the ability to quickly and efficiently communicate with your closest confidants.
articles.lead_paragraph: The address book is making a billion-dollar comeback.

articles.headline: Archrival Is Freed as Ukraine Leader Flees
articles.snippet: President Viktor F. Yanukovych fled Kiev, denouncing what he called a violent coup, as his nemesis, former Prime Minister Yulia V. Tymoshenko, was released from prison and Parliament found him unable to fulfill his duties.
articles.abstract: President Viktor F. Yanukovych fled Kiev, denouncing what he called a violent coup, as his nemesis, former Prime Minister Yulia V. Tymoshenko, was released from prison and Parliament found him unable to fulfill his duties.
articles.lead_paragraph: KIEV, Ukraine — Abandoned by his own guards and reviled across the Ukrainian capital but still determined to recover his shredded authority, President Viktor F. Yanukovych fled Kiev on Friday night to denounce what he called a violent coup, as his official residence, his vast, colonnaded office complex and other once impregnable centers of power fell without a fight to throngs of joyous citizens stunned by their triumph.
articles.byline: By Andrew Higgins and Andrew E. Kramer

articles.headline: A New Light on Regulators in the Dark
articles.snippet: Federal Reserve transcripts show a board playing catch-up with the events of 2008.
articles.abstract: Federal Reserve transcripts show a board playing catch-up with the events of 2008.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the five years that have elapsed since the direst days of the financial crisis, we’ve learned much about how the nation’s high-level banking regulators worked to keep the debacle from turning into a full-blown economic Depression. Tales of these herculean efforts have emerged in books by some of the major players, and in the exhaustive testimony they’ve presented before congressional inquisitors and others trying to determine what went wrong and why.

articles.headline: Loss Leaders on the Half Shell
articles.snippet: A nationwide binge on oysters is transforming an industry (and restaurants’ economics).
articles.abstract: A nationwide binge on oysters is transforming an industry (and restaurants’ economics).
articles.lead_paragraph: The joint is jumpin’: Three mixologists in striped dress shirts, dark slacks and suspenders pour drinks almost as fast as three shuckers send platter after platter of raw oysters to their fate. A bluesy soundtrack wafts over the standing-room-only din as patrons sip and slurp, oblivious to the crowd that has gathered outside for what can be a 90-minute wait.

articles.headline: Wisconsin’s Legacy for Unions
articles.snippet: Could a law that so swiftly deflated unions’ power become the pattern for other states? It’s labor’s worst fear.
articles.abstract: Could a law that so swiftly deflated unions’ power become the pattern for other states? It’s labor’s worst fear.
articles.lead_paragraph: Three years ago, a labor leader named Marty Beil was one of the loudest opponents of Gov. Scott Walker’s “budget repair bill,” a proposal that brought tens of thousands of protesters out to the Wisconsin State Capitol in Madison in frigid February weather. A gruff-voiced grizzly of a man, Mr. Beil warned that the bill was rigged with booby traps that would cripple the state’s public-sector unions.

articles.headline: El Chapo, Most-Wanted Drug Lord, Is Captured in Mexico
articles.snippet: Mexican marines and the police, aided by information from the United States Drug Enforcement Administration and the United States Marshals Service, took him into custody without firing a shot.
articles.abstract: Mexican marines and the police, aided by information from the United States Drug Enforcement Administration and the United States Marshals Service, took him into custody without firing a shot.
articles.lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — Just before 7 a.m. on Saturday, dozens of soldiers and police officers descended on a condominium tower in Mazatlán, Mexico, a beach resort known as much as a hangout for drug traffickers as for its seafood and surf.
articles.byline: By Randal C. Archibold and Ginger Thompson

articles.headline: Behind Gates, Bizarre Vision of Opulence
articles.snippet: After the departure of President Viktor F. Yanukovych, his sprawling compound was opened, revealing a golf course, a private zoo, classic cars and a restaurant in the form of a pirate ship, among other things.
articles.abstract: After the departure of President Viktor F. Yanukovych, his sprawling compound was opened, revealing a golf course, a private zoo, classic cars and a restaurant in the form of a pirate ship, among other things.
articles.lead_paragraph: KIEV, Ukraine — An eerie calm and a light mist shrouded President Viktor F. Yanukovych’s sprawling residential compound just outside the capital on Saturday morning as street fighters from the center of Kiev made their way inside, gingerly passing a wrought-iron gate and cautioning one another about booby traps and snipers.

articles.headline: A Hot Debate Over E-Cigarettes as a Path to Tobacco, or From It
articles.snippet: Some public health experts see e-cigarettes as a gateway to tobacco use, while others think they could help eradicate conventional cigarettes.
articles.abstract: Some public health experts see e-cigarettes as a gateway to tobacco use, while others think they could help eradicate conventional cigarettes.
articles.lead_paragraph: Dr. Michael Siegel, a hard-charging public health researcher at Boston University, argues that e-cigarettes could be the beginning of the end of smoking in America. He sees them as a disruptive innovation that could make cigarettes obsolete, like the computer did to the typewriter.

articles.headline: After Farmers Commit Suicide, Debts Fall on Families in India
articles.snippet: India’s small farmers, once the country’s economic backbone and most reliable vote bank, are increasingly being left behind.
articles.abstract: India’s small farmers, once the country’s economic backbone and most reliable vote bank, are increasingly being left behind.
articles.lead_paragraph: BOLLIKUNTA, India — Latha Reddy Musukula was making tea on a recent morning when she spotted the money lenders walking down the dirt path toward her house. They came in a phalanx of 15 men, by her estimate. She knew their faces, because they had walked down the path before.

articles.headline: Ukraine Rushes to Shift Power and Mend Rifts
articles.snippet: Lawmakers fired top cabinet members in President Viktor F. Yanukovych’s government and restored state ownership of the presidential palace.
articles.abstract: Lawmakers fired top cabinet members in President Viktor F. Yanukovych’s government and restored state ownership of the presidential palace.
articles.lead_paragraph: KIEV, Ukraine — Ukrainian lawmakers moved swiftly on Sunday to assert control over the government, racing to restore calm after a week of upheaval and bloodshed that ended in President Viktor F. Yanukovych’s flight and ouster on Saturday, and in sudden fears that the country might fall into civil war.

articles.headline: Comcast and Netflix Reach Deal on Service
articles.snippet: Comcast and Netflix announced an agreement Sunday in which Netflix will pay Comcast for faster and more reliable access to Comcast’s subscribers.
articles.abstract: Comcast and Netflix announced an agreement Sunday in which Netflix will pay Comcast for faster and more reliable access to Comcast’s subscribers.
articles.lead_paragraph: Comcast, the country’s largest cable and broadband provider, and Netflix, the giant television and movie streaming service, announced an agreement Sunday in which Netflix will pay Comcast for faster and more reliable access to Comcast’s subscribers.
articles.byline: By Edward Wyatt and Noam Cohen

articles.headline: Piers Morgan and CNN Plan End to His Prime-Time Show
articles.snippet: Three years after taking over for Larry King, Piers Morgan has seen the ratings for “Piers Morgan Live” hit some new lows. He and the network are in talks about him remaining at CNN in a different role.
articles.abstract: Three years after taking over for Larry King, Piers Morgan has seen the ratings for “Piers Morgan Live” hit some new lows. He and the network are in talks about him remaining at CNN in a different role.
articles.lead_paragraph: There have been times when the CNN host Piers Morgan didn’t seem to like America very much — and American audiences have been more than willing to return the favor. Three years after taking over for Larry King, Mr. Morgan has seen the ratings for “Piers Morgan Live” hit some new lows, drawing a fraction of viewers compared with competitors at Fox News and MSNBC.

articles.headline: How a Kingpin Above the Law Fell, Incredibly, Without a Shot
articles.snippet: The takedown of the world’s most wanted man — Joaquín Guzmán Loera, the head of a sophisticated narcotics enterprise — upended assumptions about the impunity of Mexican mobsters.
articles.abstract: The takedown of the world’s most wanted man — Joaquín Guzmán Loera, the head of a sophisticated narcotics enterprise — upended assumptions about the impunity of Mexican mobsters.
articles.lead_paragraph: MAZATLÁN, Mexico — They reacted here with utter disbelief. Joaquín Guzmán Loera, El Chapo, drug kingpin to the world, the Robin Hood of Sinaloa, had been arrested in his home state, in the resort town that is a loyal fief of his empire?

articles.headline: Fed’s Aid in 2008 Crisis Stretched Worldwide
articles.snippet: The Federal Reserve pumped hundreds of billions of dollars to nations to bolster global banks when dollars were scarce, newly released transcripts of 2008 Fed policy committee meetings reveal.
articles.abstract: The Federal Reserve pumped hundreds of billions of dollars to nations to bolster global banks when dollars were scarce, newly released transcripts of 2008 Fed policy committee meetings reveal.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Tuesday morning, Sept. 16, 2008, was perhaps the darkest time for the United States economy in modern memory — even if nobody knew it quite yet. It was barely 24 hours removed from the bankruptcy of Lehman Brothers, and a few hours before the government would rescue the insurer American International Group.

articles.headline: As His Fortunes Fell in Ukraine, a President Clung to Illusions
articles.snippet: Between the signing ceremony for a peace deal and a break to congratulate Ukraine’s Olympic team, President Viktor F. Yanukovych’s prospects took a dramatic turn for the worse.
articles.abstract: Between the signing ceremony for a peace deal and a break to congratulate Ukraine’s Olympic team, President Viktor F. Yanukovych’s prospects took a dramatic turn for the worse.
articles.lead_paragraph: KIEV, Ukraine — As his allies deserted him and throngs of people bayed for his blood almost within earshot of his office, President Viktor F. Yanukovych took time out on Friday to celebrate Ukraine’s first gold medal at the Olympic Games in Sochi, Russia. In a message of congratulations to the women’s biathlon relay team, he praised its “power and will to win.”
articles.byline: By Andrew Higgins, Andrew E. Kramer and Steven Erlanger

articles.headline: Pentagon Plans to Shrink Army to Pre-World War II Level
articles.snippet: Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel’s budget proposal would eliminate an entire class of Air Force attack jets and scale back the size of the Army not just to pre-9/11 levels, but to the force’s size in 1940.
articles.abstract: Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel’s budget proposal would eliminate an entire class of Air Force attack jets and scale back the size of the Army not just to pre-9/11 levels, but to the force’s size in 1940.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel plans to shrink the United States Army to its smallest force since before the World War II buildup and eliminate an entire class of Air Force attack jets in a new spending proposal that officials describe as the first Pentagon budget to aggressively push the military off the war footing adopted after the terror attacks of 2001.
articles.byline: By Thom Shanker and Helene Cooper

articles.headline: Yahoo Aims to More Deftly Blend Ads With Content
articles.snippet: Yahoo is starting to push into two of the hottest areas of Internet advertising: stream ads and so-called native ads.
articles.abstract: Yahoo is starting to push into two of the hottest areas of Internet advertising: stream ads and so-called native ads.
articles.lead_paragraph: SUNNYVALE, Calif. — To Marissa Mayer, the chief executive of Yahoo, fashion magazines like Vogue and InStyle have achieved the holy grail of advertising.

articles.headline: In the DeMint Era at Heritage, a Shift From Policy to Politics
articles.snippet: Under Jim DeMint, the Heritage Foundation, long known as an incubator for Republican policy ideas, has become more of a political organization feeding off the Tea Party movement.
articles.abstract: Under Jim DeMint, the Heritage Foundation, long known as an incubator for Republican policy ideas, has become more of a political organization feeding off the Tea Party movement.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Not long after Jim DeMint took over the Heritage Foundation last spring, his team summoned the staff for a meeting unlike any the decorous conservative policy organization had ever convened. Music blared in the auditorium. Policy analysts began with a few awkward jokes and then scampered about in a series of skits that laid out the foundation’s goals.
articles.byline: By Jennifer Steinhauer and Jonathan Weisman

articles.headline: Moviefone Is Hanging Up, but Its App Will Go On
articles.snippet: Overtaken by new technology and shifting consumer habits, the telephone movie listing and ticket service will be disconnected, and a free Moviefone app will be revised.
articles.abstract: Overtaken by new technology and shifting consumer habits, the telephone movie listing and ticket service will be disconnected, and a free Moviefone app will be revised.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Mr. Moviefone’s lines are going dead.

articles.headline: For Hints at Apple’s Plans, Read Its Shopping List
articles.snippet: Apple has avoided jaw-dropping takeovers in favor of a series of smaller deals, using the companies to buttress or fill a gap in products that already exist or are in development.
articles.abstract: Apple has avoided jaw-dropping takeovers in favor of a series of smaller deals, using the companies to buttress or fill a gap in products that already exist or are in development.
articles.lead_paragraph: One company used sensors to read body movements. Another recommended TV programs. Several others offered location and mapping services.
